statements.name: PROC SPDO
statements.description: Invokes the operator interface for SPD Server.

arguments.name: LIBRARY=
arguments.description: specifies the libref that represents the SPD Server domain whose files you want to manage.

statements.name: ADD ACL
statements.description: Creates new ACL entries.

arguments.name: acl
arguments.description: specifies the name of the ACL. Use a two-part name (table.column) to identify an ACL for a table column. Use a one-part name to identify an ACL for a table. The domain is inferred from the libref. You do not need to specify a name when creating a domain ACL. You can specify multiple names. Each name creates a separate ACL entry. Separate each name with a space.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: identifies the specified ACL names as the names of catalog entries in the catalog cat.

arguments.name: T=
arguments.description: identifies the catalog entry type to associate with the specified ACLs names.

arguments.name: ALTER
arguments.description: grants universal ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: GENERIC
arguments.description: specifies that the ACL name is a generic ACL.

arguments.name: GROUPALTER
arguments.description: grants group ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: GROUPREAD
arguments.description: grants group READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: GROUPWRITE
arguments.description: grants group WRITE access to the resource.

arguments.name: LIBNAME
arguments.description: creates an ACL for the domain. The owner of a domain can control access permissions to an entire domain with this option.

arguments.name: MODEL
arguments.description: specifies the name of another ACL. This option requests the software to copy all the access permissions and access list entries from this ACL.

arguments.name: PERSIST
arguments.description: specifies that the ACL is a persistent ACL. A persistent ACL entry is an ACL that is not removed from the ACL tables when the resource is deleted.

arguments.name: READ
arguments.description: grants universal READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: WRITE
arguments.description: grants universal WRITE access to the resource.

statements.name: CLUSTER ADD
statements.description: Adds a member to an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: MEMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of a new member table. To specify multiple tables, use multiple MEMBER= arguments.

statements.name: CLUSTER CREATE
statements.description: Creates a cluster table.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of the cluster to be created.

arguments.name: MEMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of a member table. To specify multiple tables, use multiple MEMBER= statements.

arguments.name: DELETE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the cluster and all its members can be permanently deleted with the CLUSTER DESTROY statement.

arguments.name: MAXSLOT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of slots, or member tables, to be allocated for the cluster.

arguments.name: UNIQUEINDEX=
arguments.description: specifies whether the unique indexes that are defined in the member tables will be validated and marked as unique in the cluster table.

statements.name: CLUSTER DESTROY
statements.description: Deletes an existing cluster table and all of its members.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of the cluster table to be deleted.

statements.name: CLUSTER FIX
statements.description: Restores removed or replaced members of a cluster table to a writable state.

arguments.name: MEMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the former member table that you want to repair.

statements.name: CLUSTER LIST
statements.description: Lists information about the members in a cluster table.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name of an output SAS data set to store the output. Qualify the data set name with a SAS Base engine libref.

arguments.name: /VERBOSE
arguments.description: specifies to write detail information about each member table. When OUT= is also specified, it adds columns named Variable Name, Minimum Value, and Maximum Value to the OUT= data set. When the OUT= option is omitted, the CLUSTER LIST statement writes output to STDOUT.

statements.name: CLUSTER MODIFY
statements.description: Modifies an existing cluster tableâ€™s metadata to include minimum and maximum values for one or more columns.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: MINMAXVARLIST=
arguments.description: specifies the name of one or more columns whose minimum and maximum values you want to add to metadata. The column names that you specify must exist in the cluster tables. The columns must not have a previous MINMAXVARLIST setting.

statements.name: CLUSTER REMOVE
statements.description: Removes members from a cluster table.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: member-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a member table to remove from the cluster. To specify multiple tables, use multiple MEMBER= statements.

statements.name: CLUSTER REPLACE
statements.description: Specifies a replacement member for a member of a cluster table.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table.

arguments.name: OLDMEMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the member table to remove from the member list.

arguments.name: NEWMEMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the new member table to replace the old table with.

statements.name: CLUSTER UNDO
statements.description: Reverts a cluster table back to its unbound tables.

arguments.name: cluster-tablename
arguments.description: specifies the name of an existing cluster table to undo.

statements.name: CONSTRAINT ADD
statements.description: Adds a table WHERE constraint to a table.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table on which to apply the table WHERE constraint.

arguments.name: where-clause-expression
arguments.description: specifies a WHERE clause.

statements.name: CONSTRAINT DESCRIBE
statements.description: Describes the table WHERE constraint on a table.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table whose table WHERE constraint you want to describe.

statements.name: CONSTRAINT REMOVE
statements.description: Removes a table WHERE constraint from a table.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table whose table WHERE constraint you want to remove.

statements.name: DELETE ACL
statements.description: Deletes existing ACLs for resources.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: deletes all existing resource ACLs for which ACLUSER has Control access.

arguments.name: acl
arguments.description: specifies the name of the ACL to delete. Use a two-part name (table.column) to identify an ACL for a table column. Use a one-part name to identify an ACL for a table. The domain is inferred from the libref. You do not need to specify a name when creating a domain ACL. Multiple ACL names can be specified. Separate the names with spaces.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: identifies the selected ACLs as names of catalog entries from the catalog cat.

arguments.name: T=
arguments.description: identifies the catalog entry type used to qualify the selected ACLs.

arguments.name: GENERIC
arguments.description: identifies the specified ACLs as generic ACLs.

arguments.name: LIBNAME
arguments.description: identifies the domain ACL.

statements.name: LIST ACL
statements.description: Lists information about ACLs.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists all existing resource ACLs for which ACLUSER has Control access.

arguments.name: acl
arguments.description: specifies the name of the ACL to list. Multiple ACL names can be specified. Separate the names with spaces.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: identifies the selected ACLs as names of catalog entries from the catalog cat.

arguments.name: T=
arguments.description: identifies the catalog entry type used to qualify the selected ACLs when the C= option is specified.

arguments.name: GENERIC
arguments.description: identifies the specified ACLs as generic ACLs.

arguments.name: LIBNAME
arguments.description: identifies the domain ACL.

arguments.name: VERBOSE
arguments.description: performs the requested table ACL listing, followed by the column ACLs for a specified table or tables. This is equivalent to a LIST ACL table followed by a LIST ACL table._ALL_.

statements.name: LIST USERS
statements.description: Lists the non-locking users that are active in the connected domain.

statements.name: LIST USERS/LOCKING
statements.description: Lists the locking users that are active in the connected domain.

statements.name: MODIFY ACL
statements.description: Modifies existing ACLs for resources.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: modifies all existing resource ACLs for which ACLUSER has Control access.

arguments.name: acl
arguments.description: specifies the name of the ACL entry that you want to modify. Use a two-part name (table.column) to identify an ACL for a table column. Use a one-part name to identify an ACL for a table. The domain is inferred from the libref. You do not need to specify a name when creating a domain ACL.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: identifies the selected ACLs as the names of catalog entries from the catalog cat.

arguments.name: T=
arguments.description: identifies the catalog entry type used to qualify the selected ACLs.

arguments.name: GENERIC
arguments.description: identifies the specified ACLs as generic ACLs.

arguments.name: LIBNAME
arguments.description: identifies the domain ACL.

arguments.name: ALTER
arguments.description: grants universal ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: GROUPALTER
arguments.description: grants group ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: GROUPREAD
arguments.description: grants group READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: GROUPWRITE
arguments.description: grants group WRITE access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOALTER
arguments.description: removes universal ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOGROUPALTER
arguments.description: removes group ALTER access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOGROUPREAD
arguments.description: removes group READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOGROUPWRITE
arguments.description: removes group WRITE access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOREAD
arguments.description: removes universal READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: NOWRITE
arguments.description: removes universal WRITE access to the resource.

arguments.name: READ
arguments.description: grants universal READ access to the resource.

arguments.name: WRITE
arguments.description: grants universal WRITE access to the resource.

arguments.name: GroupList
arguments.description: specifies the permissions that you want to assign or modify for an ACL group in the form: groupname = (Y|N,Y|N,Y|N,Y|N)

arguments.name: UserList
arguments.description: specifies the permissions that you want to assign or modify for a user in the form: username = (Y|N,Y|N,Y|N,Y|N)

statements.name: OPER
statements.description: Specifies a privileged action to perform on the connected proxy.

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: initiates a hard exit of the user proxy. If you specify the /DUMP option for a non-locking user proxy, the proxy exits with an ABORT function call, which produces a core file. If you are the operator of a locking user proxy, the /DUMP option is ignored.

arguments.name: DISCONNECT
arguments.description: drops the control socket from the user proxy to the client. This action causes the user proxy to terminate the next time it tries to communicate with the client. This termination initiates a hard exit of the user proxy.

arguments.name: INTERRUPT
arguments.description: sets a soft interrupt flag in any open tables that belong to the user proxy. The user receives a message in the SAS log that states that the job has been interrupted. If the job did not finish, the results might be incomplete. However, the user libref remains intact, and the user proxy is still viable.

statements.name: REFRESH DOMAINS
statements.description: Reloads the libnames.parm parameter file in the server session.

statements.name: REFRESH PARMS
statements.description: Reloads the spdsserv.parm parameter file in the server session.

statements.name: SET ACLTYPE
statements.description: Sets the member type for subsequent ACL operations.

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: specifies the type of resource on which the ACL action is to be applied. Valid values are DATA, CATALOG, and VIEW.

statements.name: SET ACLUSER
statements.description: Sets the user scope for subsequent ACL operations.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: specifies a user name or group name. The name must be registered in the password database.

statements.name: SET MODE OPER
statements.description: Enables you to run privileged operator commands.

statements.name: SET USER
statements.description: Connects to a non-locking proxy for the specified user ID.

arguments.name: user-ID
arguments.description: specifies a user ID that is returned by the LIST USERS statement.

arguments.name: port-number
arguments.description: specifies a proxy operator port number. The port number is optional. The proxy operator port number enables you to distinguish between two proxies that share the same user ID.

statements.name: SET USER/LOCKING
statements.description: Connects to the locking proxy for the specified user ID and thread ID.

arguments.name: user-ID
arguments.description: specifies a user ID returned by the LIST USERS/LOCKING statement.

arguments.name: THREAD=
arguments.description: specifies the thread ID associated with the user ID.

statements.name: SHOWLIBNAME
statements.description: Lists libref and table information for a connected user proxy.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists all currently assigned librefs for the selected user proxy.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: lists information about a specified libref.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists all open tables in the specified libref.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: lists information about a specific table in the libref.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists accessible tables in the librefâ€™s server connection.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: determines whether the specified table is accessible.

statements.name: SPDSCMD
statements.description: Sends SPD Server a command to run.

arguments.name: command
arguments.description: specifies a host command or a server command.

statements.name: SPDSMAC
statements.description: Prints the default values for SPD Server macro variables.

statements.name: TRUNCATE
statements.description: Removes data from a table without deleting the table structure or metadata.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table from which to remove data.
